ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class helps you acquire the speaking, listening, reading and writing skills required to basic capacity in a language and prepares you with the abilities needed to further explore the language.
I learned some more German, both Grammar and Vocab
I gained a better working knowledge of German in terms of vocabulary, grammar, reading, and listening. This was a standard L2 language class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lots of good practice and such, but vocab was a bit too tied to the book. Maybe some more useful words for college and city life

Strengths are that daily practice of vocabulary and grammar really help reinforce concepts. Weaknesses are that it assumes students do the required reading the day it is assigned, and if they don't, it can take some time to catch up in class with the exercises. It could be improved by having a quick summary or review of the grammar concepts learned from assigned reading before delving into exercises. As a typical language class, this class also has a lot of busy work, and I found myself spending a lot of time writing the 25-30 weekly forum responses and completing the two Connect homeworks each week. I wonder if all of this work is necessary for learning or if it could be cut down somehow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Good, solid teaching with a clear purpose and method. Great way to learn a language

I would only recommend this class if you need a language credit or if you are trying to take an intellectually less rigorous semester, as I was. Languages can be learned at anytime, so think about opportunity cost of choosing this class over other non-language classes.
